'}, {'number': 29, 'created': '2013-09-27 13:31:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/3fe11cdee4a898810d351c215c21116e507a1eb5', 'message': "Ensure that libvirt files are not world readable

The files that nova shares with libvirt and QEMU may contain user
sensitive information and it might be a problem if those files are
visible for all the users in the machine. These files include the images
under instances_dir, the base images and snapshots.

This patch introduces a new decorator that will change the user
file-creation mask temporarily during the call of a method, allowing
us to mark methods that shouldn't create world readable files thus
protecting them.

Also in this patch, all the calls that interact with libvirt owned files
have been modified to use rootwrap so they can still access these files
(for resizing an image, snapshoting a disk or migrating an instance).

Fixes bug 1129748

Change-Id: Ib290f8df20a9e29ed98faec221f607b685e26da4

"}, {'number': 31, 'created': '2013-11-27 16:00:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1d727c3a44861ccb90707c45e9897bb01eb1f0a5', 'message': "Ensure that libvirt files are not world readable

commit_message:
Ensure that libvirt files are not world readable

The files that nova shares with libvirt and QEMU may contain user
sensitive information and it might be a problem if those files are
visible for all the users in the machine. These files include the images
under instances_dir, the base images and snapshots.

This patch uses the decorator introduced in the previous patch, which
will change the user file-creation mask temporarily, during the call of
a method, allowing us to mark methods that shouldn't create world
readable files and thus, protecting them.

Also in this patch, all the calls that interact with libvirt owned files
have been modified to use rootwrap so they can still access these files
(for resizing or creating an image or when migrating an instance).

As a side effect, by setting the proper permissions to libvirt files and
accessing them using rootwrap, this patch avoids problems with cached file
attributes that might trigger problems as the one described in bug 1218372

Closes-Bug: #1129748
Closes-Bug: #1227027
Change-Id: Ib290f8df20a9e29ed98faec221f607b685e26da4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/78/22278/32 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ensure that the file is not world-readable. os.chmod(info_file, 0640)

commit_message:
Derive default gateway from /etc/sysconfig/network

Parse default gateway from /etc/sysconfig/network before
you go to /proc/net/route

Change-Id: I1c19db5392c9b1ddf2f7e6a9a2387b78fde78ef4
Closes-bug: 1250211
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/11/55911/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Read the default gateway directly from /etc/sysconfig/network.""" with open("/etc/sysconfig/network") as fh: for line in fh: fields = line.strip().split('=') if fields[0] == 'GATEWAY': return str(fields[1])

commit_message:
Properly mock out image_utils operations for tests

Currently image_utils unit tests write data to the
"conversion" path.  This should be mocked out rather than
interacting with the actual file system.

image_utils.temporary_file() also appears to hide OSErrors -- fixed.

Closes-Bug: #1252502

Change-Id: I3fcb6c4cb39de2f9f009be93498f89987be04241

commit_message:
Fixed URL to noVNC repo.

After merging of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/56749/
devstack tries to clone noVNC from git.openstack.org.
Returned back to github.com.

Fixes bug #1257974

Change-Id: I4eb4bc7bed72fc682ef7a12d5543aaf4840d6bc4

commit_message:
Support new volume driver for CloudByte ElastiStor
Implements: blueprint cloudbyte-elastistor-iscsi-driver-cinder

Change-Id: I2095ba68ee8fdccc76582ae28902dcf9a25faed9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/82/59182/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import base64 import hashlib import httplib import json import os import random import socket import string import uuid from cinder.image import image_utils from cinder import exception from cinder import flags from cinder.openstack.common import log as logging from cinder.volume.drivers.san.san import SanISCSIDriver from oslo.config import cfg VERSION = '1.0' LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) cb_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('cb_apikey', default='', help='API key to access CloudByte APIs'), cfg.StrOpt('cb_accountid', default='', help='CloudByte account under which\ storage volumes have to be created.'), ] FLAGS = flags.FLAGS FLAGS.register_opts(cb_opts) # # Core class which implemented all the required functionalities # class ElastistorISCSIDriver(SanISCSIDriver): FAILURE_MESSAGE = _("Failed to process request") # Default values for the properties to be sent to # CloudByte for API calls. DEFAULT_IOPS = 100 LATENCY = 15 BLOCKSIZE = 4 GRACEALLOWED = "false" COMPRESSION = "off" DEDUPLICATION = "off" NOOFCOPIES = 1 RECORDSIZE = "128k" SYNC = "standard" UNICODE = "off" FCENABLED = "false" ISCSIENABLED = "true" IOPSCONTROL = "true" TPCONTROL = "true" MEMLIMIT = "0" NETWORKSPEED = "0" CASESENSITIVITY = "sensitive" READONLY = "off" volume_stats = {} def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(ElastistorISCSIDriver, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey # creates a volume in Elastistore def create_volume(self, volume): iops = ElastistorISCSIDriver.DEFAULT_IOPS latency = ElastistorISCSIDriver.LATENCY blocksize = ElastistorISCSIDriver.BLOCKSIZE account_name = None tsm_name = None # Retrieve params from volume metadata required # to create ElastiStor storage volume. for i in volume.get('volume_metadata'): if i.key == "iops": iops = i.value if i.key == "latency": latency = i.value if i.key == "blocksize": blocksize = i.value if i.key == "account_name": account_name = i.value if i.key == "tsm_name": tsm_name = i.value volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(volume["id"]) if account_name is None: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: ElastiStor\ Account is required to create storage volume")) if tsm_name is None: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: ElastiStor\ TSM is required to create storage volume")) # Fetch the api key from ElastiStor # if it is not defined in the conf file. # This is required to # communicate with ElastiStor. if FLAGS.cb_apikey == '': # 1. Login Request # cmd = self._send_login_request(FLAGS.san_login, FLAGS.san_password) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to\ login to ElastiStor")) self.apikey = cmd.apikey # 2. Make a request to ElastiStor # to get the account id from account name. # # account_id = self._get_elastistor_accountid(account_name) if account_id is None: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to\ get Account details for the given Account name")) # #3. Make a request to ElastiStor to get Tsm details # throughput = int(blocksize)*int(iops) self._get_tsm_details(volume, volume_name, tsm_name, account_id, iops, blocksize, throughput) # #4.Make a request to ElastiStor to create a storage volume # self._create_elastistor_volume(account_name, account_id, volume, volume_name, iops, blocksize, latency, throughput) model_update = {} model_update['provider_location'] = ('%s %s %s' % (self.iscsi_portal, self.iqn, 0)) model_update['provider_auth'] = ('CHAP %s %s' % (None, None)) return model_update def create_cloned_volume(self, dst, src): if dst['size'] != src['size']: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to \ create clone to the volume in Elastistor ")) src_volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(src['id']) dst_volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(dst['id']) cmd = self._send_list_file_system(src_volume_name) self.volid = cmd.volumeid snapshotname = dst['display_name']+"clone" self._do_create_snapshot(self.volid, snapshotname) path = self._send_list_snapshots(self.volid, snapshotname) clonecmd = self._send_clone_volume(self.volid, dst_volume_name, path) if not clonecmd: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to create \ clone to the volume in Elastistor ")) def create_volume_from_snapshot(self, volume, snapshot): dst_volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(volume['id']) src_volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(snapshot['volume_id']) cmd = self._send_list_file_system(src_volume_name) self.volid = cmd.volumeid path = self._send_list_snapshots(self.volid, snapshot['display_name']) self._send_clone_volume(self.volid, dst_volume_name, path) def copy_image_to_volume(self, context, volume, image_service, image_id): self.get_iqn_and_portal(self.local_path(volume)) self.pre_process_system_call() image_utils.fetch_to_raw(context, image_service, image_id, "/dev/sbc") #self.local_path(volume)) self.post_process_system_call() #image_utils.resize_image("/dev/sdc", volume['size']) def copy_volume_to_image(self, context, volume, image_service, image_meta): self.get_iqn_and_portal(self.local_path(volume)) self.pre_process_system_call() image_utils.upload_volume(context, image_service, image_meta, "/dev/sdc") #self.local_path(volume)) self.post_process_system_call() def get_volume_stats(self, refresh=False): data = {'driver_version': '1.0', 'free_capacity_gb': 'unknown', 'reserved_percentage': 0, 'storage_protocol': 'iscsi', 'total_capacity_gb': 'unknown', 'vendor_name': 'Cloudbyte', 'volume_backend_name': 'unknown'} return data def delete_volume(self, volume, is_snapshot=False): """ Delete CloudByte Volume from device. """ self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey try: volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(volume['id']) cmd = self._send_list_file_system(volume_name) self.volid = cmd.volumeid self._do_delete() except: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to delete volume in Elastistor")) return false def get_iqn_and_portal(self, iqn): token = iqn.split(" ") self.portal = token[0] self.iqname = token[1] def pre_process_system_call(self): os.system("iscsiadm --mode \ discovery -t sendtargets --portal "+str(self.portal)) os.system("iscsiadm --mode node --targetname " + str(self.iqname) + (" --portal ") + str(self.portal) + " --login") def post_process_system_call(self): os.system("iscsiadm --mode node --targetname " + str(self.iqname) + (" --portal ") + str(self.portal) + " --logout") def create_export(self, context, volume_ref): pass def create_snapshot(self, snapshot_ref): self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(snapshot_ref['volume_id']) volume_details = self._send_list_file_system(volume_name) if not volume_details.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to fetch storage volume in ElastiStor")) self._do_create_snapshot(volume_details.volumeid, snapshot_ref['display_name']) def _do_create_snapshot(self, volume_id, name): params = { "id": volume_id, "name": name } createsnapshotCmd = CBCreateStorageSnapshot(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) createsnapshotCmd.execute() if not createsnapshotCmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to create snapshot in ElastiStor")) def delete_snapshot(self, snapshot_ref): self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(snapshot_ref['volume_id']) volume_details = self._send_list_file_system(volume_name) if not volume_details.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to fetch storage volume in ElastiStor")) path = self._send_list_snapshots(volume_details.volumeid, snapshot_ref["display_name"]) params = { "id": volume_details.volumeid, "path": path, } deletesnapshot = CBDeleteSnapshotCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) deletesnapshot.execute() if not deletesnapshot.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("ERROR: Failed \ to delete snapshot in ElastiStor")) def _create_elastistor_volume(self, account_name, account_id, volume, volume_name, iops, blocksize, latency, throughput): mount_name = str(account_name)+str(volume_name) cmd = self._send_add_qos_group_request(volume_name, mount_name, iops, volume['size'], blocksize, latency, throughput) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to add QoS group in ElastiStor")) self.qosid = cmd.qosid cmd = self._send_add_volume2_request(volume_name, volume['size'], account_id, mount_name) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to process add_volume2 request")) self.storageid = cmd.storageid cmd = self._send_add_volume_iscsi_service_request() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to process add_volume_iscsi_service request")) self.viscsiid = cmd.viscsiid cmd = self._send_update_controller_request() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to process update_controller request")) cmd = self._send_update_controller_storage_request() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to process update_controller_storage request")) cmd = self._send_update_controller_viscsiid() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to process update_controller_viscsiid request")) def local_path(self, volume, vg=None): return volume['provider_location'] def _do_delete(self): params = {} params["id"] = self.volid deleteCmd = CBDeleteFileSystem(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) deleteCmd.execute() #Generates the volume_name using volumeid def _generate_volume_name(self, id): volume_name = "vol" tokens = id.split("-") for i in tokens: volume_name = volume_name + i return volume_name # Lists Accounts in Elastistore def _get_elastistor_accountid(self, account_name): params = { "page": "1", "pagesize": "20" } cmd = CBListAccount2Command(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) cmd.execute() accounts = cmd.accountlist account_id = None for account in accounts: if account.get("name") == account_name: account_id = account.get("id") return account_id # Fetches the details of TSM def _get_tsm_details(self, volume, volume_name, tsm_name, account_id, iops, blocksize, throughput): cmd = self._send_list_tsm_request(iops, volume['size'], account_id, throughput) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to fetch ElastiStor TSMs")) found = False for i in cmd.tsms: if str(i.get("name")) == str(tsm_name): found = True self.datasetid = str(i.get("datasetid")) self.tsmid = str(i.get("id")) self.poolid = str(i.get("poolid")) self.iqn_prefix = str(i.get("iqnname")) self.iqn = str(self.iqn_prefix) + ':' + volume_name self.iscsi_portal = str(i.get("ipaddress")) + ':3260' if not found: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to get TSM details for the given TSM name")) def _send_clone_volume(self, id, name, path): params = { "id": id, "clonename": name, "mountpoint": name, "path": path, } cloneCmd = CBCloneCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) cloneCmd.execute() return cloneCmd.status def _send_list_snapshots(self, id, name): params = { "id": id } listsnapshots = CBListSnapshotsCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) listsnapshots.execute() if not listsnapshots.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to fetch snapshots for a volume in ElastiStor")) for i in listsnapshots.snapshots: if str(i.get("name")) == name: path = i.get("path") return path def _send_login_request(self, uname, passwd): encrypted_passwd = hashlib.md5(passwd).hexdigest() params = { "username": uname, "password": encrypted_passwd } loginCmd = CBLoginCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, params) loginCmd.execute() return loginCmd def _send_list_tsm_request(self, iops, size, account_id, throughput): size_in_mb = int(size) * 1024 quotaSize = str(size_in_mb) + "M" params = { "accountid": account_id, "iopsvalue": iops, "throughputvalue": throughput, "quotaSize": quotaSize } tsmCmd = CBListTsmCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) tsmCmd.execute() return tsmCmd def _send_add_qos_group_request(self, volume_name, mountname, iops, size, blocksize, latency, throughput): qosGroupName = 'QoS_' + volume_name size_in_mb = int(size) * 1024 quotaSize = str(size_in_mb) + "M" params = { "blocksize": blocksize, "datasetid": self.datasetid, "datasetname": volume_name, "graceallowed": ElastistorISCSIDriver.GRACEALLOWED, "iopscontrol": ElastistorISCSIDriver.IOPSCONTROL, "iops": iops, "latency": latency, "memlimit": ElastistorISCSIDriver.MEMLIMIT, "mountpoint": mountname, "name": qosGroupName, "networkspeed": ElastistorISCSIDriver.NETWORKSPEED, "protocoltype": "ISCSI", "quotasize": quotaSize, "throughput": throughput, "tpcontrol": ElastistorISCSIDriver.TPCONTROL, "tsmid": self.tsmid } qosCmd = CBAddQosGroupCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) qosCmd.execute() return qosCmd def _send_add_volume2_request(self, volume_name, size, accountid, mountname): size_in_mb = int(size) * 1024 quotaSize = str(size_in_mb) + "M" mountname = volume_name params = { "accountid": accountid, "tsmid": self.tsmid, "casesensitivity": ElastistorISCSIDriver.CASESENSITIVITY, "compression": ElastistorISCSIDriver.COMPRESSION, "datasetid": self.datasetid, "deduplication": ElastistorISCSIDriver.DEDUPLICATION, "fcenabled": ElastistorISCSIDriver.FCENABLED, "iscsienabled": ElastistorISCSIDriver.ISCSIENABLED, "mountpoint": mountname, "name": volume_name, "noofcopies": ElastistorISCSIDriver.NOOFCOPIES, "poolid": self.poolid, "qosgroupid": self.qosid, "quotasize": quotaSize, "readonly": ElastistorISCSIDriver.READONLY, "recordsize": ElastistorISCSIDriver.RECORDSIZE, "sync": ElastistorISCSIDriver.SYNC, "type": "volume", "unicode": ElastistorISCSIDriver.UNICODE, } volume2Cmd = CBAddVolume2Command(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) #jagani volume2Cmd.execute() return volume2Cmd def _send_add_volume_iscsi_service_request(self): params = { "volumeid": self.storageid, "status": "true" } iscsiCmd = CBAddVolumeiSCSIServiceCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) iscsiCmd.execute() return iscsiCmd def _send_update_controller_request(self): params = { "type": "qosgroup", "qosid": self.qosid, "tsmid": self.tsmid } controllerCmd = CBUpdateController(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) controllerCmd.execute() return controllerCmd def _send_update_controller_storage_request(self): params = { "storageid": self.storageid, "type": "storage", "tsmid": self.tsmid } storageCmd = CBUpdateController(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) storageCmd.execute() return storageCmd def _send_update_controller_viscsiid(self): params = { "viscsiid": self.viscsiid, "type": "configurevolumeiscsi" } viscsiCmd = CBUpdateController(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) viscsiCmd.execute() return viscsiCmd def _send_update_qos_group(self, iops, qosid): params = { "iops": iops, "latency": latency, "graceallowed": ElastistorISCSIDriver.GRACEALLOWED, "id": qosid } qosupdateCmd = CBUpdateQosGroup(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) qosupdateCmd.execute() return qosupdateCmd def _send_list_file_system(self, volume_name): params = { "page": "1", "pagesize": "20" } listfilesystemCmd = CBListFileSystem(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params, volume_name) listfilesystemCmd.execute() return listfilesystemCmd # Base class for command classes class CBCommand(object): # Static variables # METHOD_GET = "GET" METHOD_POST = "POST" API_PREFIX = "/client/api?" PARAM_COMMAND = "command=" PARAM_APIKEY = "&apiKey=" URI_SEPARATOR = '&' STATUS_SUCCESS = 1 STATUS_FAILURE = 0 def __init__(self, ipaddr, cmd, apikey): LOG.debug(_("Initialize CloudByte command %s"), cmd) self.method = CBCommand.METHOD_GET self.command = cmd self.ipaddress = ipaddr self.apikey = apikey # # params hold all the attributes that need to be # passed as part of the request. In case of GET request, # params will be part of the URL. # self.request_params = {"response": "json"} def execute(self): LOG.debug(_("Executing command: %s"), self.command) connection = httplib.HTTPSConnection(self.ipaddress) uri = self._generate_uri() connection.request(self.method, uri) self.response = connection.getresponse() LOG.debug(_("cloudbyte response message :%s"), self.response.msg) LOG.debug(_("cloudbyte response status :%s"), self.response.status) LOG.debug(_("cloudbyte connection uri :%s"), uri) # TODO check for http error data = {} self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE if self.response.status == 200: self.json_response = json.load(self.response) self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS self.successCb() else: self.failureCb() def set_request_params(self, params): self.request_params.update(params) def set_method(self, m): self.method = m def print_request_params(self): LOG.debug(_("Printing command parameters")) for key in self.request_params: LOG.debug("Param: %s value: %s" % (key, self.request_params[key])) def _generate_uri(self): uri = CBCommand.API_PREFIX + CBCommand.PARAM_COMMAND + self.command # not sure if apikey has to be sent as part of the URL if the request # is a POST request. Currently sending as part of the URL if not self.apikey is None: uri += CBCommand.PARAM_APIKEY + self.apikey # if the method is GET, loop through all the parameters and # append to the URL. self.print_request_params() for key in self.request_params: value = self.request_params[key] if not value is None: uri += CBCommand.URI_SEPARATOR + key\ + '=' + str(self.request_params[key]) return uri """ LOGIN COMMAND """ class CBLoginCommand(CBCommand): LOGIN_COMMAND = "login" def __init__(self, ipaddr, params): super(CBLoginCommand, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBLoginCommand.LOGIN_COMMAND, None) self.set_request_params(params) self.set_method(CBCommand.METHOD_POST) def successCb(self): self.apikey = self.json_response.get('loginresponse').get('apiKey') LOG.debug(_("Login successful")) def failureCb(self): LOG.debug(_("Failed to login to CloudByte server")) """ LIST TSM COMMAND """ class CBListTsmCommand(CBCommand): LIST_TSM_COMMAND = "listTsm" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBListTsmCommand, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBListTsmCommand.LIST_TSM_COMMAND, apikey) self.tsmid = '' self.iqn_prefix = '' self.poolid = '' self.iscsi_portal = '' self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): # Using the first available TSM to provision storage volume self.tsms = self.json_response.get('listTsmResponse').get('listTsm') def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ ADD QoS GROUP COMMAND """ class CBAddQosGroupCommand(CBCommand): QOS_GROUP_COMMAND = "addQosGroup" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBAddQosGroupCommand, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBAddQosGroupCommand.QOS_GROUP_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.qosid = self.json_response\ .get('addqosgroupresponse')\ .get('qosgroup').get('id') self.datasetid = self.json_response\ .get('addqosgroupresponse')\ .get('qosgroup').get('parentid') def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ ADD VOLUME COMMAND """ class CBAddVolume2Command(CBCommand): ADD_VOLUME2_COMMAND = "addVolume2" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBAddVolume2Command, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBAddVolume2Command.ADD_VOLUME2_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.storageid = self.json_response\ .get('addvolumeresponse').get('storage').get('id') def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ ADD ISCSI SERVICE COMMAND """ class CBAddVolumeiSCSIServiceCommand(CBCommand): ADD_VOLUME_ISCSI_SERVICE_COMMAND = "addVolumeiSCSIService" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBAddVolumeiSCSIServiceCommand, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBAddVolumeiSCSIServiceCommand .ADD_VOLUME_ISCSI_SERVICE_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.viscsiid = self.json_response\ .get('volumeiSCSIserviceresponse').get('viscsioptions').get('id') def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ UPDATE CONTROLLER COMMAND """ class CBUpdateController(CBCommand): UPDATE_CONTROLLER_COMMAND = "updateController" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBUpdateController, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBUpdateController.UPDATE_CONTROLLER_COMMAND, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ UPDATE QoS GROUP COMMAND """ class CBUpdateQosGroup(CBCommand): UPDATE_QOS_GROUP = "updateQosGroup" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBUpdateQosGroup, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBUpdateQosGroup.UPDATE_QOS_GROUP, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ LIST FILE SYSTEM COMMAND """ class CBListFileSystem(CBCommand): LIST_FILE_SYSTEM = "listFileSystem" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params, volume_name): super(CBListFileSystem, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBListFileSystem.LIST_FILE_SYSTEM, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) self.volume_name = volume_name def successCb(self): volumes = self.json_response.get("listFilesystemResponse")\ .get("filesystem") for vol in volumes: if vol.get('name') == self.volume_name: self.qosid = vol.get("groupid") self.volumeid = vol.get("id") import base64 import hashlib import httplib import json import os import random import socket import string import uuid from cinder.image import image_utils from cinder import exception from cinder import flags from cinder.openstack.common import log as logging from cinder.volume.drivers.san.san import SanISCSIDriver from oslo.config import cfg VERSION = '1.0' LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) cb_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('cb_apikey', default='', help='API key to access CloudByte APIs'), cfg.StrOpt('cb_accountid', default='', help='CloudByte account under which\ storage volumes have to be created.'), ] FLAGS = flags.FLAGS FLAGS.register_opts(cb_opts) # Core class which implemented all the required functionalities class ElastistorISCSIDriver(SanISCSIDriver): FAILURE_MESSAGE = _("Failed to process request") # Default values for the properties to be sent to # CloudByte for API calls. DEFAULT_IOPS = 100 LATENCY = 15 BLOCKSIZE = 4 GRACEALLOWED = "false" COMPRESSION = "off" DEDUPLICATION = "off" NOOFCOPIES = 1 RECORDSIZE = "128k" SYNC = "standard" UNICODE = "off" FCENABLED = "false" ISCSIENABLED = "true" IOPSCONTROL = "true" TPCONTROL = "true" MEMLIMIT = "0" NETWORKSPEED = "0" CASESENSITIVITY = "sensitive" READONLY = "off" volume_stats = {} def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(ElastistorISCSIDriver, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey # creates a volume in Elastistore def create_volume(self, volume): iops = ElastistorISCSIDriver.DEFAULT_IOPS latency = ElastistorISCSIDriver.LATENCY blocksize = ElastistorISCSIDriver.BLOCKSIZE account_name = None tsm_name = None # Retrieve params from volume metadata required # to create ElastiStor storage volume. for i in volume.get('volume_metadata'): if i.key == "iops": iops = i.value if i.key == "latency": latency = i.value if i.key == "blocksize": blocksize = i.value if i.key == "account_name": account_name = i.value if i.key == "tsm_name": tsm_name = i.value volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(volume["id"]) if account_name is None: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: ElastiStor\ Account is required to create storage volume")) if tsm_name is None: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: ElastiStor\ TSM is required to create storage volume")) # Fetch the api key from ElastiStor # if it is not defined in the conf file. # This is required to # communicate with ElastiStor. if FLAGS.cb_apikey == '': # 1. Login Request # cmd = self._send_login_request(FLAGS.san_login, FLAGS.san_password) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to\ login to ElastiStor")) self.apikey = cmd.apikey # 2. Make a request to ElastiStor # to get the account id from account name. # # account_id = self._get_elastistor_accountid(account_name) if account_id is None: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to\ get Account details for the given Account name")) # #3. Make a request to ElastiStor to get Tsm details # throughput = int(blocksize)*int(iops) self._get_tsm_details(volume, volume_name, tsm_name, account_id, iops, blocksize, throughput) # #4.Make a request to ElastiStor to create a storage volume # self._create_elastistor_volume(account_name, account_id, volume, volume_name, iops, blocksize, latency, throughput) model_update = {} model_update['provider_location'] = ('%s %s %s' % (self.iscsi_portal, self.iqn, 0)) model_update['provider_auth'] = ('CHAP %s %s' % (None, None)) return model_update def create_cloned_volume(self, dst, src): if dst['size'] != src['size']: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to \ create clone to the volume in Elastistor ")) src_volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(src['id']) dst_volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(dst['id']) cmd = self._send_list_file_system(src_volume_name) self.volid = cmd.volumeid snapshotname = dst['display_name']+"clone" self._do_create_snapshot(self.volid, snapshotname) path = self._send_list_snapshots(self.volid, snapshotname) clonecmd = self._send_clone_volume(self.volid, dst_volume_name, path) if not clonecmd: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed to create \ clone to the volume in Elastistor ")) def create_volume_from_snapshot(self, volume, snapshot): dst_volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(volume['id']) src_volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(snapshot['volume_id']) cmd = self._send_list_file_system(src_volume_name) self.volid = cmd.volumeid path = self._send_list_snapshots(self.volid, snapshot['display_name']) self._send_clone_volume(self.volid, dst_volume_name, path) def copy_image_to_volume(self, context, volume, image_service, image_id): self.get_iqn_and_portal(self.local_path(volume)) self.pre_process_system_call() image_utils.fetch_to_raw(context, image_service, image_id, "/dev/sbc") #self.local_path(volume)) self.post_process_system_call() #image_utils.resize_image("/dev/sdc", volume['size']) def copy_volume_to_image(self, context, volume, image_service, image_meta): self.get_iqn_and_portal(self.local_path(volume)) self.pre_process_system_call() image_utils.upload_volume(context, image_service, image_meta, "/dev/sdc") #self.local_path(volume)) self.post_process_system_call() def get_volume_stats(self, refresh=False): data = {'driver_version': '1.0', 'free_capacity_gb': 'unknown', 'reserved_percentage': 0, 'storage_protocol': 'iscsi', 'total_capacity_gb': 'unknown', 'vendor_name': 'Cloudbyte', 'volume_backend_name': 'unknown'} return data def delete_volume(self, volume, is_snapshot=False): """ Delete CloudByte Volume from device. """ self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey try: volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(volume['id']) cmd = self._send_list_file_system(volume_name) self.volid = cmd.volumeid self._do_delete() except: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to delete volume in Elastistor")) return false def get_iqn_and_portal(self, iqn): token = iqn.split(" ") self.portal = token[0] self.iqname = token[1] def pre_process_system_call(self): os.system("iscsiadm --mode \ discovery -t sendtargets --portal "+str(self.portal)) os.system("iscsiadm --mode node --targetname " + str(self.iqname) + (" --portal ") + str(self.portal) + " --login") def post_process_system_call(self): os.system("iscsiadm --mode node --targetname " + str(self.iqname) + (" --portal ") + str(self.portal) + " --logout") def create_export(self, context, volume_ref): pass def create_snapshot(self, snapshot_ref): self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(snapshot_ref['volume_id']) volume_details = self._send_list_file_system(volume_name) if not volume_details.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to fetch storage volume in ElastiStor")) self._do_create_snapshot(volume_details.volumeid, snapshot_ref['display_name']) def _do_create_snapshot(self, volume_id, name): params = { "id": volume_id, "name": name } createsnapshotCmd = CBCreateStorageSnapshot(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) createsnapshotCmd.execute() if not createsnapshotCmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to create snapshot in ElastiStor")) def delete_snapshot(self, snapshot_ref): self.apikey = FLAGS.cb_apikey volume_name = self._generate_volume_name(snapshot_ref['volume_id']) volume_details = self._send_list_file_system(volume_name) if not volume_details.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to fetch storage volume in ElastiStor")) path = self._send_list_snapshots(volume_details.volumeid, snapshot_ref["display_name"]) params = { "id": volume_details.volumeid, "path": path, } deletesnapshot = CBDeleteSnapshotCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) deletesnapshot.execute() if not deletesnapshot.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("ERROR: Failed \ to delete snapshot in ElastiStor")) def _create_elastistor_volume(self, account_name, account_id, volume, volume_name, iops, blocksize, latency, throughput): mount_name = str(account_name)+str(volume_name) cmd = self._send_add_qos_group_request(volume_name, mount_name, iops, volume['size'], blocksize, latency, throughput) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to add QoS group in ElastiStor")) self.qosid = cmd.qosid cmd = self._send_add_volume2_request(volume_name, volume['size'], account_id, mount_name) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to process add_volume2 request")) self.storageid = cmd.storageid cmd = self._send_add_volume_iscsi_service_request() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to process add_volume_iscsi_service request")) self.viscsiid = cmd.viscsiid cmd = self._send_update_controller_request() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to process update_controller request")) cmd = self._send_update_controller_storage_request() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to process update_controller_storage request")) cmd = self._send_update_controller_viscsiid() if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed\ to process update_controller_viscsiid request")) def local_path(self, volume, vg=None): return volume['provider_location'] def _do_delete(self): params = {} params["id"] = self.volid deleteCmd = CBDeleteFileSystem(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) deleteCmd.execute() #Generates the volume_name using volumeid def _generate_volume_name(self, id): volume_name = "vol" tokens = id.split("-") for i in tokens: volume_name = volume_name + i return volume_name # Lists Accounts in Elastistore def _get_elastistor_accountid(self, account_name): params = { "page": "1", "pagesize": "20" } cmd = CBListAccount2Command(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) cmd.execute() accounts = cmd.accountlist account_id = None for account in accounts: if account.get("name") == account_name: account_id = account.get("id") return account_id # Fetches the details of TSM def _get_tsm_details(self, volume, volume_name, tsm_name, account_id, iops, blocksize, throughput): cmd = self._send_list_tsm_request(iops, volume['size'], account_id, throughput) if not cmd.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to fetch ElastiStor TSMs")) found = False for i in cmd.tsms: if str(i.get("name")) == str(tsm_name): found = True self.datasetid = str(i.get("datasetid")) self.tsmid = str(i.get("id")) self.poolid = str(i.get("poolid")) self.iqn_prefix = str(i.get("iqnname")) self.iqn = str(self.iqn_prefix) + ':' + volume_name self.iscsi_portal = str(i.get("ipaddress")) + ':3260' if not found: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to get TSM details for the given TSM name")) def _send_clone_volume(self, id, name, path): params = { "id": id, "clonename": name, "mountpoint": name, "path": path, } cloneCmd = CBCloneCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) cloneCmd.execute() return cloneCmd.status def _send_list_snapshots(self, id, name): params = { "id": id } listsnapshots = CBListSnapshotsCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) listsnapshots.execute() if not listsnapshots.status == CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS: raise exception.CloudByteAPIException(_("Error: Failed \ to fetch snapshots for a volume in ElastiStor")) for i in listsnapshots.snapshots: if str(i.get("name")) == name: path = i.get("path") return path def _send_login_request(self, uname, passwd): encrypted_passwd = hashlib.md5(passwd).hexdigest() params = { "username": uname, "password": encrypted_passwd } loginCmd = CBLoginCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, params) loginCmd.execute() return loginCmd def _send_list_tsm_request(self, iops, size, account_id, throughput): size_in_mb = int(size) * 1024 quotaSize = str(size_in_mb) + "M" params = { "accountid": account_id, "iopsvalue": iops, "throughputvalue": throughput, "quotaSize": quotaSize } tsmCmd = CBListTsmCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) tsmCmd.execute() return tsmCmd def _send_add_qos_group_request(self, volume_name, mountname, iops, size, blocksize, latency, throughput): qosGroupName = 'QoS_' + volume_name size_in_mb = int(size) * 1024 quotaSize = str(size_in_mb) + "M" params = { "blocksize": blocksize, "datasetid": self.datasetid, "datasetname": volume_name, "graceallowed": ElastistorISCSIDriver.GRACEALLOWED, "iopscontrol": ElastistorISCSIDriver.IOPSCONTROL, "iops": iops, "latency": latency, "memlimit": ElastistorISCSIDriver.MEMLIMIT, "mountpoint": mountname, "name": qosGroupName, "networkspeed": ElastistorISCSIDriver.NETWORKSPEED, "protocoltype": "ISCSI", "quotasize": quotaSize, "throughput": throughput, "tpcontrol": ElastistorISCSIDriver.TPCONTROL, "tsmid": self.tsmid } qosCmd = CBAddQosGroupCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) qosCmd.execute() return qosCmd def _send_add_volume2_request(self, volume_name, size, accountid, mountname): size_in_mb = int(size) * 1024 quotaSize = str(size_in_mb) + "M" mountname = volume_name params = { "accountid": accountid, "tsmid": self.tsmid, "casesensitivity": ElastistorISCSIDriver.CASESENSITIVITY, "compression": ElastistorISCSIDriver.COMPRESSION, "datasetid": self.datasetid, "deduplication": ElastistorISCSIDriver.DEDUPLICATION, "fcenabled": ElastistorISCSIDriver.FCENABLED, "iscsienabled": ElastistorISCSIDriver.ISCSIENABLED, "mountpoint": mountname, "name": volume_name, "noofcopies": ElastistorISCSIDriver.NOOFCOPIES, "poolid": self.poolid, "qosgroupid": self.qosid, "quotasize": quotaSize, "readonly": ElastistorISCSIDriver.READONLY, "recordsize": ElastistorISCSIDriver.RECORDSIZE, "sync": ElastistorISCSIDriver.SYNC, "type": "volume", "unicode": ElastistorISCSIDriver.UNICODE, } volume2Cmd = CBAddVolume2Command(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) #jagani volume2Cmd.execute() return volume2Cmd def _send_add_volume_iscsi_service_request(self): params = { "volumeid": self.storageid, "status": "true" } iscsiCmd = CBAddVolumeiSCSIServiceCommand(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) iscsiCmd.execute() return iscsiCmd def _send_update_controller_request(self): params = { "type": "qosgroup", "qosid": self.qosid, "tsmid": self.tsmid } controllerCmd = CBUpdateController(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) controllerCmd.execute() return controllerCmd def _send_update_controller_storage_request(self): params = { "storageid": self.storageid, "type": "storage", "tsmid": self.tsmid } storageCmd = CBUpdateController(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) storageCmd.execute() return storageCmd def _send_update_controller_viscsiid(self): params = { "viscsiid": self.viscsiid, "type": "configurevolumeiscsi" } viscsiCmd = CBUpdateController(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) viscsiCmd.execute() return viscsiCmd def _send_update_qos_group(self, iops, qosid): params = { "iops": iops, "latency": latency, "graceallowed": ElastistorISCSIDriver.GRACEALLOWED, "id": qosid } qosupdateCmd = CBUpdateQosGroup(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params) qosupdateCmd.execute() return qosupdateCmd def _send_list_file_system(self, volume_name): params = { "page": "1", "pagesize": "20" } listfilesystemCmd = CBListFileSystem(FLAGS.san_ip, self.apikey, params, volume_name) listfilesystemCmd.execute() return listfilesystemCmd # Base class for command classes class CBCommand(object): # Static variables # METHOD_GET = "GET" METHOD_POST = "POST" API_PREFIX = "/client/api?" PARAM_COMMAND = "command=" PARAM_APIKEY = "&apiKey=" URI_SEPARATOR = '&' STATUS_SUCCESS = 1 STATUS_FAILURE = 0 def __init__(self, ipaddr, cmd, apikey): LOG.debug(_("Initialize CloudByte command %s"), cmd) self.method = CBCommand.METHOD_GET self.command = cmd self.ipaddress = ipaddr self.apikey = apikey # # params hold all the attributes that need to be # passed as part of the request. In case of GET request, # params will be part of the URL. # self.request_params = {"response": "json"} def execute(self): LOG.debug(_("Executing command: %s"), self.command) connection = httplib.HTTPSConnection(self.ipaddress) uri = self._generate_uri() connection.request(self.method, uri) self.response = connection.getresponse() LOG.debug(_("cloudbyte response message :%s"), self.response.msg) LOG.debug(_("cloudbyte response status :%s"), self.response.status) LOG.debug(_("cloudbyte connection uri :%s"), uri) # TODO check for http error data = {} self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE if self.response.status == 200: self.json_response = json.load(self.response) self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS self.successCb() else: self.failureCb() def set_request_params(self, params): self.request_params.update(params) def set_method(self, m): self.method = m def print_request_params(self): LOG.debug(_("Printing command parameters")) for key in self.request_params: LOG.debug("Param: %s value: %s" % (key, self.request_params[key])) def _generate_uri(self): uri = CBCommand.API_PREFIX + CBCommand.PARAM_COMMAND + self.command # not sure if apikey has to be sent as part of the URL if the request # is a POST request. Currently sending as part of the URL if not self.apikey is None: uri += CBCommand.PARAM_APIKEY + self.apikey # if the method is GET, loop through all the parameters and # append to the URL. self.print_request_params() for key in self.request_params: value = self.request_params[key] if not value is None: uri += CBCommand.URI_SEPARATOR + key\ + '=' + str(self.request_params[key]) return uri """ LOGIN COMMAND """ class CBLoginCommand(CBCommand): LOGIN_COMMAND = "login" def __init__(self, ipaddr, params): super(CBLoginCommand, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBLoginCommand.LOGIN_COMMAND, None) self.set_request_params(params) self.set_method(CBCommand.METHOD_POST) def successCb(self): self.apikey = self.json_response.get('loginresponse').get('apiKey') LOG.debug(_("Login successful")) def .get('addvolumeresponse').get('storage').get('id') self.quotasize = vol.get("quota") self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ UPDATE FILE SYSTEM COMMAND """ class CBUpdateFileSystem(CBCommand): UPDATE_FILE_SYSTEM = "updateFileSystem" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBUpdateFileSystem, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBUpdateFileSystem.UPDATE_FILE_SYSTEM, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ DELETE FILE SYSTEM COMMAND """ class CBDeleteFileSystem(CBCommand): DELETE_FILE_SYSTEM = "deleteFileSystem" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): super(CBDeleteFileSystem, self).__init__(ipaddr, CBDeleteFileSystem.DELETE_FILE_SYSTEM, apikey) self.set_request_params(params) def successCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_SUCCESS def failureCb(self): self.status = CBCommand.STATUS_FAILURE """ LIST ACCOUNTS COMMAND """ class CBListAccount2Command(CBCommand): LIST_ACCOUNT_COMMAND = "listAccount2" def __init__(self, ipaddr, apikey, params): commit_message:
Ensure_resource on dnsmasq package

As dnsmasq is sometimes required by other modules,
in particular ones that are not in puppet-openstack,
this can cause duplicate declaration issues. By
using ensure_resource, we can avoid these problems
and both modules can declare the package.

Backport of I32f29bcac3cf67a2644b3e5eb50621f8e27b1cb1

Change-Id: Id7c66c20b62890df51c37f608087234a5b470eae

commit_message:
Don't have tox install pre-release software

Override the tox pip install command to avoid using the "--pre" option
which is the default in tox.  "--pre" means "Include pre-release and
development versions."  By default, pip will only install stable
versions of software, and that is the behavior we want.

Change-Id: I3aa2a69c5bae54932137c78cc711236a0ca24602

commit_message:
Add multi-worker support

Since https://review.openstack.org/#/c/37131/ got merged, Neutron
supports now multiple worker processes for API server.

Change-Id: Ib01240c39de21306892f4f92e0ba3ecb56837a7c
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>
(cherry picked from commit 64c452b4fb8b955639bc57b483f619224a23be83)
Backport to havana: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/60082/
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/45/61345/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*api_workers*] # (optional) Number of separate worker processes to spawn. # The default, 0, runs the worker thread in the current process. # Greater than 0 launches that number of child processes as workers. # The parent process manages them. # Defaults to: 0 # $log_dir = '/var/log/neutron', $api_workers = '0' 'DEFAULT/api_workers': value => $api_workers;

commit_message:
Ensure_resource on dnsmasq package

As dnsmasq is sometimes required by other modules,
in particular ones that are not in puppet-openstack,
this can cause duplicate declaration issues. By
using ensure_resource, we can avoid these problems
and both modules can declare the package.

Change-Id: I32f29bcac3cf67a2644b3e5eb50621f8e27b1cb1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/46/61646/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add -U to pip install command in tox.ini

Ask pip to upgrade packages in the virtualenv so that a long-lived
virtualenv is still kept up to date as external dependencies change.

Change-Id: I5a57debd5c4bc03e6d00d3801be614d9b895c508

commit_message:
db: make compatible with SQLAlchemy 0.8

Argument assert_unicode is deprecated in SQLAlchemy 0.7.
Also it is removed from SQLAlchemy 0.8.
Arguments convert_unicode, unicode_error, and _warn_on_bytestring
seem to cause problems with SQLAlchemy 0.8.

Closes-bug: 1235829

Change-Id: I713dd446756398805404400d05b1d0927601dd97
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/57/59157/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: length=length, convert_unicode=False, length=None, convert_unicode=False,
deleted_lines: length=length, convert_unicode=False, assert_unicode=None, length=None, convert_unicode=False, assert_unicode=None,

commit_message:
Extract suffix from req URL to avoid escaping dots

Usernames and their hosts can contain dots. As such,
user CRUD requests may end in ids that contain one
or more fullstops. Our request router can interpret
these as file suffixes and our methods and as a
result, truncates these ids improperly.

This change inspects the request object in these
cases, looks for a possibly misinterpreted suffix,
and reattaches the suffix to the id. This means
that escaping . in requests shouldn't be necessary.

Closes-Bug: #1252327

Change-Id: I74c4d6694baba44ebe0018eedac2ae5c4773b370

commit_message:
Set the provision_state to DEPLOYFAIL

Set the provision_state to DEPLOYFAIL instead of ERROR when the deploy
failed. The DEPLOYFAIL state should be used for this problem specific
where ERROR is more generic.

Change-Id: I87c75dd8be46950792643303f79d57f9a7da9d0d

commit_message:
Clean up duplicated change-building code in objects

Almost every object thus far has done this:

  updates = {}
  changes = self.obj_what_changed()
  for field in changes:
        updates[field] = self[field]

to get a dict of updates to apply to the database. This patch adds
that as part of the base object and makes every place that does
the above to just use that.

It's a port from a patch in nova ,link to the origional patch:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/45353/

Change-Id: I8d2616ecc2c88cf4b21e7e8193f5b985407ed869
Closes-Bug: #1259527
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/43/61143/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def obj_get_updates(self): """Returns a dict of updated fields and their new values.""" updates = {} for field in self.obj_what_changed(): updates[field] = self[field] return updates

commit_message:
Rework patch validation on Ports

This makes use of the complex type objects of WSME and creates a type
to validate json patch format.

Change-Id: I17ea33efec16146d4ece90fd0ef5123faaacefb0
Partial-Bug: #1223847

commit_message:
Fix deleted_at timestamp in usage tests

* use the mgmt api to look up the instance for the deleted_at time

Closes-Bug: 1236620

Change-Id: I96d46f9f48616124f59efeb1292cfe0768b6318c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/90/61590/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add JsonPatchType class

This patch adds the JsonPatchType class for API parameter validation with
WSME. This class will be used to replace some of the custom validation
functions we have in the api/utils.py.

Change-Id: I233cd273854eae5ed4d8856d4af3e2f8e2309dce
Partial-Bug: #1223847
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/94/60194/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import webtest import wsme class TestPatchType(base.FunctionalTest): def _patch_json(self, params, expect_errors=False): class MyPatchType(types.PatchType): @staticmethod def mandatory_attrs(): return ['mandatory'] @staticmethod def internal_attrs(): return ['internal'] class MyRoot(wsme.WSRoot): @wsme.expose(None, body=[MyPatchType]) @wsme.validate([MyPatchType]) def test(self, patch): pass my_root = MyRoot(['restjson']) app = webtest.TestApp(my_root.wsgiapp()) return app.patch_json('/test', params=params, headers={'Accept': 'application/json'}, expect_errors=expect_errors) def test_valid_patches(self): valid_patches = [{'path': '/extra/foo', 'op': 'remove'}, {'path': '/extra/foo', 'op': 'add', 'value': 'bar'}, {'path': '/foo', 'op': 'replace', 'value': 'bar'}] ret = self._patch_json(valid_patches, False) self.assertEqual(ret.status_int, 200) def test_internal_attr(self): patch = [{'path': '/internal', 'op': 'replace', 'value': 'foo'}] ret = self._patch_json(patch, True) self.assertEqual(ret.status_int, 400) def test_mandatory_attr(self): patch = [{'op': 'replace', 'path': '/mandatory', 'value': 'foo'}] ret = self._patch_json(patch, False) self.assertEqual(ret.status_int, 200) # mandatory attrs can't be removed patch = [{'op': 'remove', 'path': '/mandatory'}] ret = self._patch_json(patch, True) self.assertEqual(ret.status_int, 400) def test_missing_required_fields(self): missing_path = [{'op': 'remove'}] ret = self._patch_json(missing_path, True) self.assertEqual(ret.status_int, 400) missing_op = [{'path': '/foo'}] ret = self._patch_json(missing_op, True) self.assertEqual(ret.status_int, 400) def test_invalid_op(self): patch = [{'path': '/foo', 'op': 'invalid'}] ret = self._patch_json(patch, True) self.assertEqual(ret.status_int, 400) def test_invalid_path(self): patch = [{'path': 'invalid-path', 'op': 'remove'}] ret = self._patch_json(patch, True) self.assertEqual(ret.status_int, 400) def test_add_to_root(self): patch = [{'path': '/foo', 'op': 'add', 'value': 'bar'}] ret = self._patch_json(patch, True) self.assertEqual(ret.status_int, 400) def test_add_replace_with_no_value(self): patch = [{'path': '/extra/foo', 'op': 'add'}] ret = self._patch_json(patch, True) self.assertEqual(ret.status_int, 400) patch = [{'path': '/foo', 'op': 'replace'}] ret = self._patch_json(patch, True) self.assertEqual(ret.status_int, 400)

commit_message:
Fix missing policy enforcement in CFN API

Currently the CreateStack and UpdateStack actions aren't correctly
enforcing the policy, so add calls to _enforce which fixes that,
and rework the test to illustrate the issue.

Change-Id: Ia5c2e65512ab9d1c163171f8617c081ab96745e5
Closes-Bug: #1256049
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/52/61452/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: change sphinx requirement to < 1.1.99 because 1.2b3 exists
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-11 11:34:11.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/3c2963e445e30f6b2b55eaca4816efc4033e6800', 'message': 'change sphinx requirement to < 1.1.99 because 1.2b3 exists

< 1.2 seems right, except 1.2b3 is also < 1.2 by python version
rules. In the gate, with the mirror, this seems to work. However

Change-Id: I719536a0754bb532b800c52082aeb4e2033e174f
'}]
commit_message:
change sphinx requirement to < 1.1.99 because 1.2b3 exists

< 1.2 seems right, except 1.2b3 is also < 1.2 by python version
rules. In the gate, with the mirror, this seems to work. However
on local envirnments 1.2b3 is often pulled, and local doc builds
break.

Change-Id: I719536a0754bb532b800c52082aeb4e2033e174f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/84/61384/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
change sphinx requirement to < 1.1.99 because 1.2b3 exists

< 1.2 seems right, except 1.2b3 is also < 1.2 by python version
rules. In the gate, with the mirror, this seems to work. However
on local envirnments 1.2b3 is often pulled, and local doc builds
break.

Change-Id: I719536a0754bb532b800c52082aeb4e2033e174f

commit_message:
Skip autoscaling test until more reliable

AutoScalingTest has issues which will require rethinking how
this test is implemented, including:
- the optimal ConsumeStopSeconds will depend on the overhead
  of boot time, which varies greatly between bare metal and
  virt-on-virt
- every combination of distro/release/flavor will result in a
  different baseline memory usage, making it difficult to
  determine the ScaleDownThreshold to set

This change skips this test and tracks against the bug:
Partial-Bug: #1257575

Change-Id: I0695a7efacdbeab39c895a97cb45496fcaf97e35

subject: Workaround Cinder "wishlist" bug 1255593 for multi-backend volume_clear
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-07 21:54:05.000000000', 'files': ['lib/cinder'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/7103a84e3900502648e81bd4313b777f2da63f92', 'message': 'Workaround Cinder "wishlist" bug 1255593 for multi-backend volume_clear

Cinder currently only applies the volume_clear setting from the DEFAULT
section of cinder.conf if you're using a single backend.

The Cinder team has determined this is a 'wishlist' item to propagate
volume_clear to each backend, but it does impact usability and
performance.

To improve the performance of running Tempest with multi-backends in the
gate, workaround the bug in devstack.

Related-Bug: #1255593

Change-Id: Ia0ff5422f53eeda9a3ac4336eefec3b9bdea6da2
'}]
commit_message:
Workaround Cinder "wishlist" bug 1255593 for multi-backend volume_clear

Cinder currently only applies the volume_clear setting from the DEFAULT
section of cinder.conf if you're using a single backend.

The Cinder team has determined this is a 'wishlist' item to propagate
volume_clear to each backend, but it does impact usability and
performance.

To improve the performance of running Tempest with multi-backends in the
gate, workaround the bug in devstack.

Related-Bug: #1255593

Change-Id: Ia0ff5422f53eeda9a3ac4336eefec3b9bdea6da2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/94/60694/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(mriedem): Work around Cinder "wishlist" bug 1255593 if [[ "$CINDER_SECURE_DELETE" == "False" ]]; then iniset $CINDER_CONF lvmdriver-1 volume_clear none iniset $CINDER_CONF lvmdriver-2 volume_clear none fi

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-11 14:46:28.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/metadata/agent.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/test_metadata_agent.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/bd4a85d67f091382752d75b95f9cfd076431f30e', 'message': "Add X-Tenant-ID to metadata request

passed in the metadata request to nova and nova then checks that

Change-Id: I2b8fa2f561a7f2914608e68133abf15efa95015a
Closes-Bug: #1235450
"}]
commit_message:
Add X-Tenant-ID to metadata request

Previously, one could update a port's device_id to be that of
another tenant's instance_id and then be able to retrieve that
instance's metadata. In order to prevent this X-Tenant-ID is now
passed in the metadata request to nova and nova then checks that
X-Tenant-ID also matches the tenant_id for the instance against it's
database to ensure it's not being spoofed.

DocImpact - When upgrading OpenStack nova and neturon, neutron
            should be updated first (and neutron-metadata-agent
            restarted before nova is upgraded) in order to minimize
            downtime. This is because there is also a patch to nova
            which has checks X-Tenant-ID against it's database
            therefore neutron-metadata-agent needs to pass that
            before nova is upgraded for metadata to work.

Change-Id: I2b8fa2f561a7f2914608e68133abf15efa95015a
Closes-Bug: #1235450

commit_message:
move rpc_setup to the last step of __init__

rpc setup should be the last stuff in agent initialization
so that the rcp message handler(the agent instance itself)
can have a fully initialized agent instance.

Change-Id: I58c966e2c8ee92c307b565932e867b5d1ec73b67
Closes-Bug: #1259088

commit_message:
Use /info to check if SLO is enabled

The functional tests have some hokey detection of SLO support that
pre-dates the /info API, but we can do better now.

Also moved the SLO check up inside the setUp method so that skipping
the SLO tests should be somewhat faster now.

Change-Id: I645718b459d794a9a97770f7162934558c94f3e8

subject: Debug env for tox
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-31 17:40:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/428ec23670765fb25eb60874c1f164505c7487e9', 'message': "Debug env for tox

Running a test with pdb was difficult because testr captures
output and causes pdb prompt to quit.

This change adds a debug environment that runs
 python -m testtools.run discover --load-list test_to_run

as described in
 https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Testr#Debugging_.28pdb.29_Tests

Now you can do a command like

 tox -e debug keystone.tests.test_auth.AuthWithTrust.test_v3_trust_token_get_token_fails

and when it hits your breakpoint you'll get a prompt.

Change-Id: I2b5dc81f4652dc89ecbcc7c785245a81cf77a1ca

commit_message:
Debug env for tox

Running a test with pdb was difficult because testr captures
output and causes pdb prompt to quit.

Tips for how to run with debug are provided here:
 https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Testr#Debugging_.28pdb.29_Tests

This change puts these commands into a debug env in tox.ini so
you can do a command like

 tox -e debug test_v3_trust_token_get_token_fails

or, for more granularity:
 tox -e debug keystone.tests.test_sql_migrate_extensions.EndpointFilterExtension
 tox -e debug keystone.tests.test_sql_migrate_extensions.EndpointFilterExtension.test_downgrade

and when it hits your breakpoint you'll get the debug prompt.

Change-Id: I2b5dc81f4652dc89ecbcc7c785245a81cf77a1ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/89/54789/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Added help note in attach volume dialog

Added help note in Horizon's dashboard (Edit attachments dialog), in order to
inform that device name may not match the proposed one.
The intention is to provide more information when device names don't match due
to hypervisor limitations or naming convention.

Change-Id: I39828542047a2f2149815e2beba1099501aa755e
Partial-Bug: #1217874

commit_message:
Ensure api_paste_conf is an absolute path

If api_paste_conf is specified as a relative path and the directory from
where the nova-api service is started contains a file with the same
name, the wsgi loader won't try to find the absolute path to that file
which is required when not passing the base directory to the
paste.deploy library.

This change ensures the config_path is an absolute path so it can be
found by the paste.deploy library.

Closes-Bug: #1259183
Change-Id: I0eb6ef1d69d302634b8c842449f997ec10c13933

commit_message:
Make obj_from_primitive() preserve version information

When we hydrate an object from a remote client, we need to know
the version and not pretend like it's just the current version.

Related-Bug: #1258256
Change-Id: I68bbfa18addfb7e51efc10a757135e338302a787

commit_message:
Explicitly set keystone auth_strategy

Explicitly set keystone as the auth_strategy. Also moved sysctl
load command closer to where the related config changes
actually appear.

Closes-Bug: #1258295
backport: havana
Change-Id: I8ae977c8eac984c2f56b9318b6369e02847546d1
(cherry picked from commit ec5d0950104f65fdc55e8e8e6821358982bcd293)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/33/61333/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para> Use the <command>sysctl</command> command to ensure the changes made to the <filename>/etc/sysctl.conf</filename> file take effect: </para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>sysctl -p</userinput></screen> <para> It is recommended that the networking service is restarted after changing values related to the networking configuration. This ensures that all modified values take effect immediately: </para> <para>Configure Neutron to use Keystone for authentication by editing the <filename>/etc/neutron/neutron.conf</filename> file. </para> <substeps> <step> <para> Set the <literal>auth_strategy</literal> configuration key to <literal>keystone</literal> in the <literal>DEFAULT</literal> section of the file: </para> <programlisting language="ini">auth_strategy = keystone</programlisting> </step> <step> <para> Add these lines to the <literal>keystone_authtoken</literal> section of the file: </para> <programlisting language="ini">auth_host = <replaceable>controller</replaceable> </step> </substeps>
deleted_lines: <para>With system network-related configurations, you might need to restart the network service to activate configurations, as follows:</para> <para>Configure the core networking components. Edit the <filename>/etc/neutron/neutron.conf</filename> file and add these lines to the <literal>keystone_authtoken</literal> section:</para> <programlisting language="ini">[keystone_authtoken] auth_host = <replaceable>controller</replaceable> <para>To activate changes in the <filename>/etc/sysctl.conf</filename> file, run the following command:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>sysctl -p</userinput></screen>

The default value for "auth_region" assumes "RegionOne" rather

commit_message:
Explicitly define "auth_region" in Neutron metadata_agent.ini

The default value for "auth_region" assumes "RegionOne" rather
than "regionOne" which causes the metadata agent to generate
authentication errors.

Change-Id: I0d3395a215eea7b3e3a9760a81e5f72a6bf523a4
Closes-Bug: #1259344
(cherry picked from commit 534aeb30c7a2c38a2f4294eea62c81e501bc9f2a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/32/61332/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: auth_region = regionOne auth_region regionOne</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/metadata_agent.ini DEFAULT \ <note><para>The value of <literal>auth_region</literal> is case-sensitive and must match the endpoint region defined in Keystone.</para></note>

commit_message:
Keystone Verify - Further clarity on the use of ADMIN_PASS

A user reported an issue that the documentation was not clear as to where
the "ADMIN_PASS" paramater came from. I've clarified this further and
added a link to the relevant step to enforce it's origin. Also corrected
a very minor typo.

Note that this is now aware of the way that Debian-based platforms configure
the users in Keystone and links to the relevant page for further assistance.

Change-Id: Ie1722812386591fa0563b57a4127b0042da1ee40
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1252281
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/69/61269/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: Request a authentication token using the <literal>admin</literal> user and the password you chose for that user.</para>

commit_message:
Enables E711,E721,E712 pep8 rules

Updates tox.ini to reduce ignored rules.

Updates novaclient/v1_1/shell.py and
novaclient/v3/shell.py for E712 violation.

commit_message:
Speed up FlowDetail.find

Looking up task by its uuid is quite frequent operation, so it worth
having it executed faster. For that, this commit changes how task
details are stored: we now use uuid -> task detail dictionary instead of
list.

Change-Id: Ie098bf982b5fbca799e0f0f1e736eebff06f9671

commit_message:
Fixed PEP8/flake8 issues

We need to fix PEP8/flake8 issues corresponding to the new
hacking rules that got added before we can update to the
new global requirements.

Change-Id: Iff995139d258549ff9a8e3e5018e964efa2ab152

commit_message:
Fix errors for create_endpoint api in version2

1. Create an endpoint without 'service_id' should return a 400 Bad Request
with appropriate message instead of 500 Internal Server Error.
2. Empty urls should be discarded.

Change-Id: I535467ec35fe2ae738ecae0a4f20d19ff4f001ec
Closes-Bug: #1250765
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/76/56176/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # service_id is necessary self._require_attribute(endpoint, 'service_id') # null urls can be discarded in both legacy_endpoint_ref.pop('%surl' % i)

commit_message:
Libvirt: Making the video driver element configurable

hw_video_model can be provided via the image properties in Glance.
It may be set to one of the following values: "vga", "cirrus", "vmvga", "xen" or "qxl",
as these are currently being supported by libvirt.

    glance image-update \
       --property hw_video_model=qxl \
       [image]

DocImpact
Partially implements blueprint libvirt-video-driver-selection
Change-Id: Ie710eb9d8d094865d651373c6f9882f1ac12b49a

commit_message:
Rename instance_type to flavor in baremetal virt driver

Goes through the baremetal virt driver and associated classes and tests
and renames instance_type to flavor. This patch does not handle renaming
instance_type in nova.test.utils or the instance_type_id column in the
instance db model so those parts are left unchanged here.

DocImpact: Renames the 'instance_type_extra_specs' option in the
baremetal group to 'flavor_extra_specs'.

Part of blueprint flavor-instance-type-dedup

Change-Id: I4405464aea2b2e2142ed1207fb9c25ed9e863cb0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/77/59277/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove the api_thread_pool option from libvirt driver

This gave us the option to select if calls to libvirtd are done
in a native thread or directly. This was added because the person
who wrote the thread pool code was afraid of regressions for existing
deployments. But now we have enough features in nova that require
that this is always set to True or else users can have issues with
them. To this point the firewall overrode this option to make
sure that its call was always in a native thread no matter the
value of this option was.

The reasons behind this were discussed during this review:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/57000/

Closes-Bug: #1254811

DocImpact: removes api_thread_pool flag from the libvirt group

Change-Id: Ifad7f1bdf2af69e4fcd6f9a04bf2f7ff5251afd6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/41/59941/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: from eventlet import tpool # execute in a native thread and block current greenthread until done if not CONF.libvirt.api_thread_pool: # NOTE(maoy): the original implementation is to have the API called # in the thread pool no matter what. tpool.execute(self._conn.nwfilterDefineXML, xml) else: # NOTE(maoy): self._conn is an eventlet.tpool.Proxy object self._conn.nwfilterDefineXML(xml)

commit_message:
Periodic task _heal_instance_info_cache can now use slave db

This periodic task will now use a slave db for all reads if a slave
is configured. For deployments with no slave, behavior remains unchanged.

Change-Id: Iafda7ff7a895b21a75c6d3923269f45bc84c81b0
Partially-implements: blueprint periodic-tasks-to-db-slave

commit_message:
libvirt: add a test to guard against set_host_enabled raising an error

Commit cc70e3a adds a finally block to _get_new_connection to
automatically disable the host if making a connection to libvirt fails.

The set_host_enabled method currently swallows all exceptions which is
good so it doesn't mask the original libvirt failure in
_get_new_connection, but we need to have a test that makes sure that
isn't unintentionally regressed. This patch adds the test.

Related-Bug: #1257644

Change-Id: I4beec053794edc75ef2d0060a05285f7ed0b99ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/84/60584/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_set_host_enabled_swallows_exceptions(self): # Tests that set_host_enabled will swallow exceptions coming from the # db_api code so they don't break anything calling it, e.g. the # _get_new_connection method. conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), True) with mock.patch.object(db, 'service_get_by_compute_host') as db_mock: # Make db.service_get_by_compute_host raise NovaException; this # is more robust than just raising ComputeHostNotFound. db_mock.side_effect = exception.NovaException self.assertIsNone(conn.set_host_enabled('fake-mini', False))

commit_message:
Extends V3 servers api for pci support

All pci passthrough code is merged into nova, but the API does not support.
this patch extends the servers to show PCI information for instance and compute
node. This is a part of PCI APIs, for more information see the  blueprint.

Partially implement blueprint pci-api-support

Change-Id: I99eeeca67983c49433ab0079f490a454d250f5e0

commit_message:
Add a trivial functionaltests/run_tests.sh

I need a simple entry point to running the functional test suite for the
devstack gate job.  This script provides that.  Right now it's quite
trivial and just runs nose.  We'll probably want to update this to testr
later, but it really doesn't matter much right now since there's only a
single test case.

Change-Id: I6cd2ce8d11addf70195e2df2e11161cfd58f04bd

subject: Fix the scope to share a server between tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-11 03:51:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/22613c4cd8af39d6c77598bc99f183db6885ce31', 'message': 'Fix the scope to share a server between tests

In test_server_actions.py, one server is created in setUpClass() and
the server would be shared between all tests.
If the server status is not 'ACTIVE' before each test, rebuild_server()
deletes it and rebuilds a server again.

The server_id scope which is passed to rebuild_server() is class variable
not instance variable. In addition, the server_id scope which is stored
with the return value of rebuild_server() is instance variable like the
following:

  [[instance]]                         [[class]]
  self.server_id = self.rebuild_server(self.server_id)

If we need to rebuild a server, the server_id, which is passed to rebuild_
server(), cannot be changed due to its scope. As the result, many server
creations happens in each test. Then it causes "Quota exceeded" exception.

This patch fixes the scope of server_id for sharing the same server between
each tests.

Change-Id: I72b4aa73a6c77cce3a8e777d4f78913fb0986f66
Fixes-Bug: #1257641

commit_message:
Fix the scope to share a server between tests

In test_server_actions.py, one server is created in setUpClass()
and the server would be shared between all tests.
If the server status is not 'ACTIVE' before each test, rebuild_
server() deletes it and rebuilds a server again.

The server_id scope which is passed to rebuild_server() is class
variable not instance variable. In addition, the server_id scope
which is stored with the return value of rebuild_server() is
instance variable like the following:

  [[instance]]                         [[class]]
  self.server_id = self.rebuild_server(self.server_id)

If we need to rebuild a server, the server_id, which is passed to
rebuild_server(), cannot be changed due to its scope. As the result,
many server creations happens in each test.
Then it causes "Quota exceeded" exception.

This patch fixes the scope of server_id for sharing the same server
between each tests.

Change-Id: I72b4aa73a6c77cce3a8e777d4f78913fb0986f66
Closes-Bug: #1257641
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/13/61313/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.__class__.server_id = self.rebuild_server(self.server_id)

commit_message:
Changes trove_client.client.HTTPClient to
trove_client.HTTPClient

Reasons:
 - trove shell is not working.
 - troveclient.client is now imported as trove_client
   but while calling the method it has been called
   as trove_client.client

Changes:
- Changes trove_client.client.HTTPClient to
  trove_client.HTTPClient in troveclient/v1/client.py

Change-Id: I12b0a0d9792f69ad04a17c36a8de134f233afc85
Closes-Bug: #1259882

subject: Sync oslo threadgroup.py to fix wait & stop methods
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-09 17:44:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/5c251f1ce3de269ed8670588c5f2368356703977', 'message': 'Make wait & stop methods work on all threads

Previously, ThreadGroup.wait and ThreadGroup.stop would iterate over
the self.threads list and call the wait or stop method on each one.
This list could potentially be edited concurrently by the _thread_done
callbacks and remove some items in the list.  As a result, the wait
method would not actually wait for all threads in the thread group.

Change-Id: Ia49d7096180b2942cf49b1f0dacde3c5e933337c
Closes-Bug: #1196525
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-12-10 16:45:09.000000000', 'files': ['heat/openstack/common/threadgroup.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/edff59db51a9eb213932a4c2b622ae1e4d18805d', 'message': 'Sync oslo threadgroup.py to fix wait & stop methods

Sync oslo threadgroup.py to 25ff65e955b7ef1091722224f7c71f14fc971354 so
we include the fix for bug #1196525, which resolves a problem where the
wait and stop methods would not actually wait for/stop all threads in
the thread group.

Change-Id: Ia49d7096180b2942cf49b1f0dacde3c5e933337c
'}]
commit_message:
Sync oslo threadgroup.py to fix wait & stop methods

Sync oslo threadgroup.py to 25ff65e955b7ef1091722224f7c71f14fc971354 so
we include the fix for bug #1196525, which resolves a problem where the
wait and stop methods would not actually wait for/stop all threads in
the thread group.

Change-Id: Ia49d7096180b2942cf49b1f0dacde3c5e933337c

subject: Have tox install via setup.py develop
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-11 17:00:19.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-refresh-config/commit/d137cbceb5036e4a63289110cc7a8b4228892b88', 'message': 'Have tox install via setup.py develop

tox 1.6 was released, which means that we can now take advantage of
the feature we added to it - which is using setup.py develop to
install the code into the virtualenv. The logic was taken from
run_tests.sh - so the performance issues around using tox vs. using
install_venv should now be gone.

Additionally, override the tox pip install command to avoid using the
"--pre" option which is the default in tox.  "--pre" means "Include
pre-release and development versions."  By default, pip will only
install stable versions of software, and that is the behavior we want.

Change-Id: Ida5e440d1bdb9f8e9031277ea53a02d2ef171438
Co-Authored-By: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>

commit_message:
Have tox install via setup.py develop

tox 1.6 was released, which means that we can now take advantage of
the feature we added to it - which is using setup.py develop to
install the code into the virtualenv. The logic was taken from
run_tests.sh - so the performance issues around using tox vs. using
install_venv should now be gone.

Additionally, override the tox pip install command to avoid using the
"--pre" option which is the default in tox.  "--pre" means "Include
pre-release and development versions."  By default, pip will only
install stable versions of software, and that is the behavior we want.

Change-Id: Ida5e440d1bdb9f8e9031277ea53a02d2ef171438
Co-Authored-By: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-refresh-config refs/changes/96/61496/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: minversion = 1.6 skipsdist = Trueusedevelop = True install_command = pip install -U {opts} {packages}

commit_message:
Have tox install via setup.py develop

tox 1.6 was released, which means that we can now take advantage of
the feature we added to it - which is using setup.py develop to
install the code into the virtualenv. The logic was taken from
run_tests.sh - so the performance issues around using tox vs. using
install_venv should now be gone.

Additionally, override the tox pip install command to avoid using the
"--pre" option which is the default in tox.  "--pre" means "Include
pre-release and development versions."  By default, pip will only
install stable versions of software, and that is the behavior we want.

Change-Id: Ida5e440d1bdb9f8e9031277ea53a02d2ef171438
Co-Authored-By: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>

commit_message:
Add zypper element

This provides some customizations for zypper based distributions (e.g.
openSUSE and SLES). It is heavily inspired by the yum element and sets up
zypper to cache downloaded package outside of the chroot so that they can be
reused to speed up subsequent builds.

Change-Id: I775c921ee19cf7d1180fb68c1b7857ea6245a77d
